ABSTRACT
The modeling of a random process as the output of a linear, causal, and causally inveit- ibie filter has been considered by a number of authors. Various approaches that have been used are summarized here. The spectral multiplicity of the random process plays a funda- mental role in this problem and permits a general and unified approach. In this framework, necessary or sufficient conditions for unit multiplicity are obtained on the system's impulse response function and on the output process itself. The role of spectral multiplicity in linear least-mean-square estimation is also clarified.
I. INTRODUCTION AND PRELIMINARY REMARKS
It is often important to model a random process x(t) in a simple and mathe- matically tractable way. A popular model which possesses these two properties and in addition provides some physical insight into the generation and sto- chastic structure of the process is the one where the process x (f) is considered to be the output of a causal, linear, time-varying system h(t, r) with a white noise input n (t).
This model is often encountered in problems of detection, estimation, and optimization. Of particular interest in most of these problems is the possibility of "inversion" or "equivalence"; that is, the possibility of obtaining the white noise n (t) by passing the output x (t) through another causal linear system.
It is not known precisely which processes admit this model. Over the last two decades considerable attention has been paid to this question, and it turns out that there are substantial classes of processes which can be modeled in this manner. However, there is a tendency to assume this structure for any random process, and it is important to know when the assumption is justified. A uni- fied and general approach is provided by the notion of spectral multiplicity of a random process, as introduced by Cramer [1,2] and Hida [3]. In this frame-

III. CONDITIONS ON THE PROCESS
The second problem is to determine conditions on a given process x (?), so that it can be modeled in an invertible way as the output of a causal, linear system to a white noise input; that is

Again, the restricted model of a lumped linear system that can be described by a finite number of first-order linear differential equations has often been adopted. However, there have been more general treatments. Stear [6] gives an outline of work done on various aspects of this subject. Brandenburg [8] considers first the problem in its generality and then concentrates on the state- variable model in which case the solution to the problem depends upon a Riccati differential equation. Again, the invertibility of the representation has not been emphasized, and it is usually implicit in the particular model employed. Recently, Kailath, Frost, and Geesey [11-15] have contributed several papers on the subject concentrating on the causal invertibility of the representation. However, the problem is not examined explicitly in the multiplicity framework and the processes are usually restricted to be Gaussian. In a subsequent section

IV. AN APPLICATION TO LEAST-MEAN-SQUARE ESTIMATION
A technique widely used in the construction of linear least mean-square estimators is the "prewhitening" method introduced by Bode and Shannon [26] for wide sense stationary processes and applied since for a much wider class of processes. This technique consists of passing the observation process y(t) = x(f) + n(t) through a prewhitening filter and then through an estimating filter, providing a factorization of the best estimator. It is apparent from the previous discussion that this factorization is possible without loss of information only when y(t), or, more correctly, its "integral" Y(t) has multiplicity one. Conse- quently, whenever the process Y(f) contains a deterministic component or is pnd with multiplicity greater than one, the prewhitening method is not applicable.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The modeling of a random process as the output of a linear, causal, and causally invertible filter has been considered by a number of authors. Various approaches that have been used are summarized here. The spectral multiplicity of the random process plays a fundamental role in this problem and permits a general and unified approach. In this framework, necessary or sufficient conditions for unit multiplicity are obtained on the system's impulse response function and on the output process itself. The role of spectral multiplicity in linear least-mean-square estimation is also clarified.
